Reviews.Content: A little peace and quiet in the city First of all, I was a little reluctant to stay here. You had to call the hotel directly and I do not speak French. I wrote out a little to say, but was surprised when I was answered in English. I had to fax over a letter stating my information and then Fed Ex a check to hold our room as they do not take credit cards. But I will say this was all worth it. You cannot beat the location and the hosts are friendly and you feel right at home. We had the small room which was small but cozy and I loved it. We had a great time in Paris. Make sure you eat at Au Relois down the road...ask them where it is. I had the best meals there of all my life..and the hot chocolate was to die for.I will be back one day, I know it!
Reviews.Author: skankyjo

Reviews.Content: Hidden Delight If you are seeking a charming abode in a romantic part of Paris, you can't do better. The proprietress, Sophie Canipel, is delightful and so accommodating. We lucked into the little efficiency next door and pretended for a week that it was home. She gave us a bottle of wine for the occasion and filled us with options of new exhibits around town. We are Americans in India and the Ermitage has become motivation for a layover on our long journeys. The location, price, room and hospitality make it a very popular place, so book early.
Reviews.Author: shellbell27

Reviews.Content: Charming Small Hotel       Our large and pretty bedroom
Reviews.Author: Gardenfriend

Reviews.Content: Little oasis in Paris My mother and I stayed at Ermitage for 4 nights in July. It was Mum's first big trip overseas, and this hotel was the perfect place to bring her. The fact that it is not a sterile, minimalist hotel means a lot - it has character and charm. Breakfast on our patio was lovely, overlooking the gardens and neighbouring houses. A sure antidote to crazy days of sightseeing and travel on the Metro. Our twin room was sufficiently large, beautifully decorated, beds were comfy, bathroom was spotless. The fact that my Mother had just had a knee replacement meant that getting in and out of the bath (no shower) was a challenge, but travelling poses many challenges and she took it in her stride. The other great thing is that the hotel is on the quiet side of Montmartre, not on the tourist beat. This meant we felt part of a neighbourhood rather than just another pair of travellers. The friendly Cafe Au Relais just down the road from the hotel contributed to this with their down to earth service, homely food, delicate wines and punchy coffee. We became instant regulars.
Reviews.Author: JessicaNZ

Reviews.Content: A jewel in Montmartre A little late posting this review, I know (2 years) but I felt I really should sing the praises of this lovely little hotel. Like one of the other reviewers, I brushed off my schoolgirl French and telephoned the owners, only to find that Madame spoke good English! She was absolutely charming and when I said that we would be celebrating my 50th birthday that weekend, she said that she would book us into one of the rooms with the terrace.Walking up from the Metro on a hot July afternoon wasn't as gruelling as it might have been - I don't think my husband or I had realised how close to Sacre-Coeur we would be staying but there it was, floating like a huge ornate meringue above us! The welcome at the hotel was one of the warmest we have ever experienced. The room was perfect (huge armoire and plenty of hangers!), the bathroom quirky but once we had mastered the art of showering without soaking the bathroom (over-bath shower), we were fine!Our breakfast each morning was served on the pretty terrace - the window-cill was low enough to hop out of the tall window. The coffee and croissants or baguettes were fresh and delicious.We were at the back of the hotel with views over the skyline of Paris and despite the fact that France was playing Italy in the World Cup Final on my birthday, we weren't disturbed by noise.We have both said that we would go back to this hotel in a heartbeat - Paris in the Spring would be good!
Reviews.Author: Menolly56

Reviews.Content: Loved it!       Small but clean and cosy
Reviews.Author: Neensmm

Reviews.Content: Adorable       The view of Paris from the end of the block
Reviews.Author: BrooklynGirlNewYork

Reviews.Content: cozy and cute I stayed at this wonderful little place for six nights together with my boyfriend. We stayed in one of the studios with a separate entrance, which was perfect for us. The location was wonderful just close to the very touristic area around the Sacr茅 Coeur, but still a bit away from the worst crowd. The area around Lamarck-Caulaincourt is very charming and it easily feels as if you are one of the locals.The room was very small but sooo charming with flowered walls and matching bedspreads, so we didn't really mind. I mean, we had no intention of spending our Paris stay hiding in the hotel room!.. A big armoir swallowed all our clothes which also was good... And the view from the window was splendid overlooking a small backyard and the whole of Paris. We woke up each morning to the birds chirping and the sun in our eyes :) The small kitchenette and the (small) bathroom were very fresh and nice. There was no cooking plate, but a microwave where you could make your food.The only thing that could bother us were the pillows (more like tubes) and the fact that the walls weren't exactly sound proof. That actually seems to be very common in Parisian hotels, though. The fact that you have to walk a bit from the metro to get there (which some of the reviews say) didn't bother us a bit!The staff was helpful and the cleaning was great!That studio was perfect and we felt as if we had our own little place above the rooftops in Paris :) I would definitely stay there again, even if I didn't get that studio. But I would definitely ask for a room with a view - that made our day every morning.
Reviews.Author: kanin1

Reviews.Content: How a small hotel should be Paris needs no introduction, but nestled on a quiet backstreet just behind the Sacre Coeur is the Ermitage Hotel, and it is quite possibly one of the best kept secrets Paris has to offer. This small hotel is outstandingly good value.Staying at the Ermitage is a delight. It is a small hotel with very friendly staff, who speak English well and give French lessons as they prepare breakfast. All the little touches. The breakfast is quaint and continental with freshly baked croissants, bottomless bowls of chocolat chaude, and proper cups of coffee. The whole place feels authentically French and catapulted straight out of some Moulin Rouge bohemian dreamworld. The style is art nouveau with authentic charm, gilded chandeliers, checkerboard floors, and a lot of textured fabric on the walls, all of which giving the place a very rich sensual feel. Our bedroom had an enormous amount of personality and unique character- it felt opulent and decadent, whilst cosy and intimate. A truly unique hotel at an extremely reasonable price. The hotel has Lonely Planet and Rough Guide guide books which can be borrowed for the duration of your stay, and the steps of the Sacre Coeur are just metres away... and from there atop Montmartre , breathtaking views of the most celebrated romantic city. Paris je t'aime. Especially magical by night.
Reviews.Author: boho_hobo

Reviews.Content: The best of quaint paris There is probably nothing I will say here that has not already been said by the previous reviewers, based off which and a NY times review I had made my reservation at this quaint place. Yes making a reservation is an arduous process particularly when you are coming from a country that is not in the western hemisphere. That said, it was worth it! The rooms are old in a nice way. It is clean and comfortable. Take the rooms in the basement (11 and 12) and they open out to a beautiful terrance garden. The hosts (mother and daughter duo, the third generation is also becoming a part of it!) are wonderfully friendly, warm and helpful. Of course the best part is you walk out of the hotel and you can see the beautiful sacre couer cathedral. The metro is close enough as are many many many lovely bistros and cafes around the area.
Reviews.Author: JyotiG

Reviews.Content: Very Pretty, and here's what you need to know... This is a very charming hotel run by two women in the Montmartre district. But there are things I'd like others to know: The hotel only takes cash  the owners make you send them a deposit after you make the reservation (by fax) in a Euro Traveler's Cheque form -- not that easy to attain in the US. The rooms are beautiful, fabric walls, heavy doors and a free breakfast of croissants, coffee, etc. But don't plan on lounging in your room all day because they want you to leave by 11:30am or noon so they can clean the rooms and they'll call you to ask, when you sortie? Rooms, by the way, they clean better than any hotel I've ever stayed in, but they touch your things and rearrange everything, just, I think, to be super tidy. They are very nice and helpful in that French way. You must stay as long as you've promised as I heard others try and leave early to much dismay and their deposit taken. It really is a lovely hotel but I think it's important for people to know what they're walking into.
Reviews.Author: FancyTraveler10

Reviews.Content: Classic French Warmth, Hospitality, and Charm !!       Garden Pation outside Room #12
Reviews.Author: queenices

Reviews.Content: Very Hospitable - a home away from home I recently just returned from my first trip to Paris and planned to only stay 2 nights at most at this hotel. However, since getting to know the wonderful family who runs the hotel (Maggie, Dominique, etc.), I decided to stay a total of 5 nights with side trips to other parts of France in my total stay of 2 weeks. The rooms were decorated so beautifully in old-style Parisian decor and the hotel is only 2 blocks away from the famous Sacre Cour cathedral. The area is quiet and clean and there are numerous restaurants and shopping nearby. The metro is a short walk as well. The family麓s hospitality was tremendous, and I found myself looking forward to the hot chocolate and croissants outside my door every morning. Maggie was especially helpful with planning the side trips and you immediately sense her pride in this truly beautiful city.Montemarte, the area where the hotel is located has a very bohemian feel to it (Picasso, Hemingway and Renoir all lived here at one point). I believe one of them said of the flowered wall paper typical of Parisian rooms ... either the wall paper goes or I go.. right before he died.. At the risk of sounding morbid, I mention it because the rooms definitely reflect this decor motif, adding to the whole experience of Montemarte.I definitely recommend this hotel if you ever have an opportunity to explore Paris. Oh, and I might as well also recommend Hemingway麓s A Moveable Feast as he wrote this in Cuba, about his time in Paris. Safe travels!
Reviews.Author: ElizaNY

Reviews.Content: Beautiful Paris This was our first time to Paris and my husband and I were on a budget. Sophie and Maggie were very accomodating and were as friendly as ever. Our room was immaculate every time we returned. The clean staff folded our clothes and put them in the closet. No maid in the US would ever do that!The Montmartre neighborhood is just wonderful! And the value was fine. I was warned that hotels in France are not what Americans are used to, so I was prepared for anything.The location of the Ermitage is tricky though and although we enjoyed our stay we probably won't return. I will book much farther in advance and get an even better location.When returning from long days of walking around Paris (which you walk about 5 miles a day), Montmartre is in a very hilly neighborhood and the walk from the Metro to the Ermitage is approximately a 5 block walk uphill. I am in very good shape and don't mind, but this would be bad for someone not in shape. Also Montmartre is loaded in stairs. Don't stay in this neighborhood if you have trouble with them.The Metro is a very easy way to travel around Paris. It is almost identical to the New York City subway system and maps are posted everywhere. It is also a good way to get around on a budget only costing about 2 Euro a day.The bed we had at the Ermitage was not the most comfortable either, and the pillows are not standard pillows. Now to get to the funky part.....the bathroom. If you are taller then 5'10 and are larger then 140lbs then look for another hotel. The bathroom we had was teeny weeny. My huband who is slender and 6' tall had quite a challenge. When on the toilet your knees come out the front door. If you want to shut the door then you have to sit sideways. Then there is the bathtub that is not meant to stand in. You can practically kill yourself in it. It does not have a level floor. It is meant to sit in it with your knees up in front of you. Needless to say, it was very very uncomfortable.Also, in regards to the breakfast, it consists of only, coffee, tea, or hot chocolate and a small baguette with jelly  butter and a croissant. Not exactly a breakfast to get through a busy morning on. There are, however, creperies in the square on the other side of the Sacre Coeur.Wear very comfortable walking shoes, otherwise you'll regret it!However, We were in Paris none the less, and who could complain about that!!
Reviews.Author: Winddancer1

Reviews.Content: Warmth  This charming hotel, was more than accomodating to my family as we traveled through Paris enroute to Dijon this past June. While the hotel doesn't boast many of the amenities that many Americans are used to, the Canipel family made those differences seem insignificant with their warmth and attentiveness.As we were traveling with our four year old son, they gave us great advice on traveling from the airport and train stations, as well as navigating the metro system. It was a joy.While the hotel is removed from central Paris, the view from Mont Martre is spectacular and well worth the metro ride. Waking up to hear the bells of Sacre Couer is a memorable experience.We look forward to returning in the future, and highly reccomend it to anyone who is looking to truly experience European warmth and charm.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Quintessential French, Warm, Friendly Owners, Well Recommended I noted this hotel and others from the feedback off this site. So, I chose to stay here based on reviews.Please take the negative reviews with a grain of salt, having stayed here,personally, I find them laughable.My wife and I stayed at the Ermitage in early July 05'It was a thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish. We ended up getting a small studio on the second floor in the adjoining building, and it was perfect.The Ermitage is a couple of streets below Sacre Coeur,and, after a day of touring the city, we came back to our studio to rest, recharge, and went up to Sacre Coeure at 9:30 p.m., it was surprisingly quite light out, as July has some long days at this Latitude. The Monte Marte area is unique and contains some of the neatest homes, old cobblestone roadways, Art Museums etc. This establishment is just a short walk from the artists in the square behind Sacre Coeur.Can't say enough about the variety of boulangeries, pattiseries(deli's and pastry shops), you can shop for your breakfast, lunch,or dinner on a daily basis. It's a great way to vacation. Tons of restaurants, cafes, all within easy walk, or the subway. ATM is a short walk down the street, Hotel takes CASH - NO Credit Cards. Hotel owner is as friendly and genuine as they come. Excellent Value, well run, clean.
Reviews.Author: intrepidFlorida

Reviews.Content: Value and Elegance My husband and I recently stayed at this wonderful little hotel. We had a lovely two bedroom apartment. The view of the city of lights from our bedroom was an extra bonus. It was spotlessly clean and tastefully decorated. Sophie and her staff were very friendly and helpful. It was just a short walk to the Sacre Coeur de Montmartre. Be aware that this area has a lot of steps to climb to reach the top, but there is the funiculaire (like a cable car) and also a tourist trolley for those whose have trouble with stairs. The view is well worth seeing. Go for the sunset and wait for the lights of Paris to dazzle you.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Love the People, love the place Stayed here over a month while attending Culinary School. We loved it. Maggie was wonderful and made us feel like family. Yes, it's off the beaten path but it is clean, nice and from the patio you can see all of paris. I have stayed at some pretty posh hotels in Paris, but Love ermitage.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: The best kept secret in Paris! Since 1985 I have stayed with the Canipels at their beautiful Ermitage hotel when visiting Paris, and all I can say is my experiences have been really wonderful! My sister even spent her honeymoon there; another sister and a brother has also stayed there with their spouses; everyone loved it! You simply can't beat it for the money! The ambiance of all the different rooms; the signature French breakfast brought to your door each morning; the views - and the close proximity to Sacre Coeur - all make the Ermitage the best kept secret in Paris! All guests were even given a free bottle of champagne for New Year's during the Millennium! Anyone who doesn't love this hotel should skip Paris altogether and just visit another city!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Wonderful place to stay I'm astonished at some of the comments here, as I've stayed here with the Canipels each year for a number of years, am always completely satisfied, and now won't stay anywhere else in Paris. And I've stayed in plenty of other places in Paris over the years. No, the hotel is not on the Champs Elysees, but I prefer the privacy of the location, which is mere steps from Sacre Coeur. For the price, there's nowhere else in Paris that you can get such great hospitality, nicely kept rooms, and a wonderful view of all of Paris from the hills of Montmartre. Can't say enough good about this hotel--highly recommended.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Not Good My wife and I were very disappointed in this hotel and decided to cut our stay short after the first night. The area is far from the main sights and on a very boring street. The interior is interesting if you like wierd decor and are into the Adams Family style of decorating. We were willing to overlook these negative aspects until a cockroach greeted us in the shower. The lack of hot water topped it all off. When we told the manager we would be leaving early she became very rude. Of course they charged us for the unused night - no problem, we were just glad to get out of there.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Do not stay here Do not stay at this hotel. It is too far from the main sights and it was not a pleasant place at all. I can't think of anything positive about my stay at the Ermitage. I found many other hotels during my visit to Paris that were much nicer for the same price and in much better locations. My advice would be to look elsewhere.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: The Jewel Box       Ermitage Room
Reviews.Author: churby

Reviews.Content: Warm reception and a great experience My fiancee and I stayed three nights at Hotel Ermitage in March 2004. It was a great experience. We were lucky enough to get room 10, which is on the top floor and has an amazing view. Breakfast is brought to the room. The family that runs it speak English well. They are very helpful. The neighborhood is fantastic and we had no problem getting to the major sights in the city center using the Metro.
Reviews.Author: melvinPickles

Reviews.Content: Terrible Experience at Ermitage Bad Experience. The dark, dreary foyer gave us the creeps upon entering and things only got worse. We had to skip showers because they had no hot water. The breakfast was stale, greasy croissants and luke warm coffee. They charged us the 3-person rate even though our child isn't even school aged. When we questioned their policy of charging extra for our small child, the same rate as 3 adults would pay, they became argumentative and made snide comments about the United States. Their parting words were, we don't need your business anyway. This hotel ruined our Paris vacation.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: An intriguing tiny hotel A lovely place to stay if you are looking for a quiet, restful location in Paris. Rooms are very clean and decorated in a fashion appropriate to the age of the building and the district. The lady who runs the hotel is quite delightful. Excellent value as well.On the down side, not very convenient metro connections to most of the touristy parts of town. Bathroom in the room we had was tidy, never could figure out how to close the door. With these reservations, recommended.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Nice Clean, nice, happy, quiet, fun. Far away BUT I like being outside of the tourist zone 7/24. GREAT family running the place.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Too far away My partner and I just got back from a trip to France and we stayed at the Ermitage for three days. It is a very nice little hotel, really a bed and breakfast, and very clean and nicely decorated. The hotel is in Montmarte, a neighborhood of Paris that is a short metro ride to the tourist sites. However, we were in Paris for the latest rounds of transit strike (which is still ongoing and has been for some time) and with the access to the rest of Paris cut off by the interruption in bus and subway services we were only able to see part of the city. My advise is to splurge a little more and stay closer to the Louvre and other attractions. Its nice to be able to come back to your room for a break in the site filled day and take a load off without having to travel too far to get there. This hotel, although great in many other ways was just too far away from the center of things for us.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Charming family hotel This is a charming hotel run by the Canipel family is right near the Sacre Coeur basilica and Monmartre. Rooms are pleasant and airy, and tastefully decorated. Breakfast is served en suite, or on the outdoor terrace if you are lucky enough to have one of the two rooms on the bottom floor. M. Canipel and her husband are lovely and gracious hosts. Best way to get there on publictransportation is to take the Metro to Abbesses and then take the Monmartre funicular. Turn right after exiting the funicular, and walk *down* the hill to Rue Lamarck.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
